title: Conditionals in Python: if/elif/else, blocks, and readable decision logic
content:
Conditionals let your program choose different actions based on data. In Python, the basic tools are `if`, `elif`, and `else`.

---
## 1) The simplest if-statement

```python
x = 10
if x > 5:
    print("x is bigger than 5")
```

Python uses **indentation** to define the block (the code controlled by the `if`).

---
## 2) if/else: choose between two paths

```python
age = 17
if age >= 18:
    print("adult")
else:
    print("minor")
```

---
## 3) elif: multiple choices
Use `elif` to avoid deeply nested `if` statements.

```python
score = 82
if score >= 90:
    grade = "A"
elif score >= 80:
    grade = "B"
elif score >= 70:
    grade = "C"
else:
    grade = "D"

print("grade", grade)
```

---
## 4) Comparing the same value to several constants

```python
cmd = "start"

if cmd == "start":
    print("starting")
elif cmd == "stop":
    print("stopping")
elif cmd == "status":
    print("show status")
else:
    print("unknown command")
```

---
## 5) Truthiness: if checks a truth value
Many expressions can be used directly in `if`.

```python
items = []
if items:
    print("has items")
else:
    print("empty")

name = ""
if not name:
    print("missing name")
```

---
## 6) A small practice script: validate and respond

```python
text = "42"

if text.isdigit():
    n = int(text)
    if n % 2 == 0:
        print("even")
    else:
        print("odd")
else:
    print("not a number")
```
